text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with Rouladen
that's right we're gonna stuff in rolled
beef just like a German grandmother
would or at least this is how I think
they would do it I'm not actually
friends with any German grandmother's
and believe me that's not from lack of
trying but that aside I consider this
one of the greatest examples of German
comfort food and this is one of those
classic dishes that really does look
impressive and complicated to a guest
and yet as you'll see is incredibly
simple to make so let's go ahead and get
started and first up let's meet the meat
so for this you're going to need a
couple thin pieces of beef I would say
slice about five or six ounces would be
ideal I'm actually using some bottom
round here but similar cuts like rump
roast or even chuck would also work and
by the way if you have any seams or
muscle separation like I have right here
you want to position that on the end
you're going to start rolling from and
that will make more sense in a few
minutes but I did want to point that out
and did I get this media to discount
because it started to oxidize and wasn't
all nice and bright red I'd rather not
say and the first thing we're going to
want to do is season this very
generously with kosher salt and freshly
ground black pepper and once that's been
accomplished we are going to spread the
surface of that meat with a generous
amount of mustard and I'm going to use
some good old Dijon but apparently
you're supposed to use German mustard
whatever that is but I'm pretty sure any
mustard is going to do the trick here so
we'll go ahead and we'll smear both
those pieces of meat with some kind of
mustard at which point we'll place down
our bacon so I'm going to put about two
slices of thick-cut bacon and I'm
actually going to break that piece off
right there because I don't want to go
all the way to the bottom okay we went a
little bit of plain beef to finish the
rolling with so we'll leave a couple
inches at the bottom sounds bacon and by
the way if you enjoy the smokiness of
bacon this would be great for you but if
you don't and want something possibly a
little more authentic you could use
pancetta which is pretty much the same
thing it's just not smoked today we're
going to place down our bacon and then
once that set we will sprinkle over a
generous amount of paprika or as I refer
to it training cayenne and not only is
that going to add a little touch of
bitter sweetness it's also going to kind
of stain that bacon red and help achieve
what you'll see is a gorgeous color
inside and then once those have been
peppery good we will add some thinly
sliced onions and we'll want to place
them across this way perpendicular to
the direction we're going to roll these
in and again just like the bacon don't
all the way to the bottom and then once
our onions down we'll also lay down some
slices of dill pickle exactly three
pieces each one at the top one in the
middle and one near the bottom and then
once our pickles have been placed in
perfect position we are ready to roll
these up so we'll go from the larger end
to the smaller end and of course do your
best to keep everything inside and we'll
roll these nice and tight continuing all
the way to the end so I'll go ahead and
roll up my second one in case you
weren't clear and then once our beef has
been successfully stuffed and rolled up
we need to secure this somehow so it
stays together and I'm going to do that
with three pieces of butcher twine using
that very simple knot I've showed you
many times just slide the string under
twist it through at least two or three
times which will allow you to cinch it
up nice and tight and then we'll finish
the knot and that's it
and obviously you're doing this with the
seam down so we'll do one in the middle
and then one on either end which should
hold this together very securely and I
should mention a lot of people like to
use toothpicks for this but I find the
toothpicks unsightly dangerous and
generally annoying so that's up to you
you are the Kaiser of these rolls so you
decide they both work and then once
those are tied and we've trimmed off our
excess string we'll go ahead and season
the outside and I hope a lot of you were
thinking right now why do you just
season both sides of the meat when it
was on the cutting board
won't that have been easier yes it would
have I wish I thought of it but anyway
we'll go ahead and season the outside
at which point is time to brown these
over medium-high heat in a little bit of
vegetable oil in whatever pan or pot
you're going to cook these in so since
I'm only making two I'm going to use
this saucepan but this recipe can
totally be scaled up to as many as you
want
you just have to increase the size your
cooking vessel that's all and when our
beef has been properly browned we will
remove that from the pan turn our heat
down to medium-low and make the gravy in
which we're going to cook our Rouladen
so like I said turn your heat down to
medium-low and we will add a chunk of
butter and some flour because we're
going to make a roux and yes I
definitely should have let that butter
melt before adding the flour but I'm
impatient and I tend to just throw it in
which makes it so much harder but that's
alright eventually the butter melted and
I was fine and what we'll do is we'll
cook that Roux for just a minute at
which point we will dump in our cold
beef broth or beef stock and by the way
we can just go ahead and dump that all
in at once
remember hot Roux cold liquid no lumps
so
just relax all you Lumpa folks out there
you could just dump it all in it once
and then just whisk variously for a
minute to combine and once you feel like
that's been incorporated we will raise
our heat to medium-high and bring this
up to a simmer and like all roux based
sauces it's not going to thicken until
it starts to bubble which you can see
happening right here so as you can see
it's not a super thick mixture but it
definitely has some body to it and at
this point we will transfer our roulade
back in along with of course any
accumulated juices and then as far as
the rest of this procedure goes it's so
easy all we're going to do is reduce our
heat to very low to maintain a very very
gentle simmer and then all we need to do
is cover that and let it simmer for
about an hour and a half or until the
meats tender and what you want to do a
couple times during that hour and a half
is uncover it and give them a turn and
by the way that gravy level is perfect
they don't have to be covered they are
going to cook beautifully just like that
so like I said once in a while we'll
uncover it and give those a turn and
we'll simply keep cooking until like I
said the meat is tender which generally
is going to take about an hour and a
half but of course it's going to depend
on how big you made your Rouladen
and of course you don't have to guess if
it's done you can just use a fork or the
tip of a knife to give it a little test
and it should slide in fairly easily
which mine did and then once our meat is
tender what we want to do is remove that
tool bowl to rest for about five minutes
or so while we finish off the gravy and
all I mean by that is turn the heat up
to high and maybe reduce it just a
little it might be okay but I did reduce
mine for about five minutes just to
thicken it up a little more and
obviously you're going to taste it for
salt and I didn't show it but I did skim
the fat off because I don't want my
plate looking too greasy and then once
our sauce is set and our meat is rested
about five minutes we are ready to serve
and yes you can serve it whole just like
this but for me it looks a little too I
don't know Log ish so I highly suggest
you do it I'm about to do now give it
one slice at about a 45 degree angle
just like that to reveal one of the most
gorgeous stuffed in rolled beef dishes
in history look at that now that is some
precise German engineering right there
so we'll go ahead and we'll cut that in
half at an angle and then we'll go ahead
and serve that up I did mine on some
braised cabbage and roasted parsley
potatoes and then last but not least do
not forget to ladle over that amazing
gravy in that beef Rouladen
least the Chef John version is done and
as gorgeous as it looks the taste and
texture were just as impressive and even
though we used very tough very lean beef
for this the fat that bacon is provided
an incredible richness almost an
artificial marbling if you will there
really helps make this so moist and
delicious and of course that gravy we
stood everything in is amazing in fact
my only regret here was not making
mashed potatoes because that gravy was
so incredible so I did feel like a
little bit of a dummkopf but I don't
want to be too hard on myself because
all in all this really was goober
wunderbar and by the way if you're
wondering where I learned all this
German from Hogan's Heroes of course but
anyway that's it beef Rouladen like I
said in the intro it only looks
complicated and impressive but in fact
is actually a very simple recipe so I
really do hope you give this a try head
over to food wishes comm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
